intro: Pseudolycopodiella meridionalis, commonly known as the southern clubmoss, is a small, evergreen fern that thrives in shaded, moist environments. It belongs to the family Lycopodiaceae and is characterized by its compact, creeping growth habit. The plant produces small, scale-like leaves and has sporangia that are clustered in strobila, typical of its evolutionary lineage. It is native to regions of the southern United States and parts of Mexico. Due to its unique morphology and ecological niche, it is of interest to botanists studying ancient plant lineages.
